text:
I had a situation where the I was running JMeter in distributed mode with 4 
machines, 3 running in server mode and a one in GUI mode.

  I started the test, and the application server I was testing crashed. This 
caused the one server running in GUI mode that was collecting the data to core 
after an hour or so, the test was to run overnight. 

  The 3 instances of that were started and controlled by the GUI instance 
continued to run without indication that they were still running. When I 
restarted the GUI it did not have the remote stop test active. It did though 
have the remote start active.

  I would think that if the GUI instance, the one collecting and running the 
statisics on the data dies during the test that the clients should stop what 
they are doing. It would seem that the test would be over at that point.

  I understand because of the nature of JMeter that this may be inappropriate 
verify this every time a call is made or data is given back to the controlling 
instance but it maybe it can be done in a interval like once every X minutes or 
something.
creator: danderson_75@yahoo.com

text:
This has been fixed. 

If the client crashes, the remote server will detect that it cannot send a 
sample back to the client; it will log an error and end the test. The server 
then waits for the next test to be sent.
creator: sebb@apache.org
